title: What is your honest review of Marvin Gaye's 1971 album, What's Going On? - Quora

response.answer_text: Probably the greatest groove-anchored album ever made, the album hits a mellow funk pocket on its amazing title track and never lets up. Though the album is composed of nine tracks, and side two mixes up the formula a bit with Right On and Wholy Holy, in most ways the album feels like one long composition, and is, on a musical level, breathtaking start to finish, with multiple tracks - What’s Goin’ On, Mercy Mercy Mercy Me (The Ecology), Inner City Blues - rating amongst the greatest soul recordings ever produced. My one knock on the album, and the only reason I feel it is more a top-25, top-50 all time record and not a top-ten all-time album as most contemporary aggregator cites have it, is that just like Stevie Wonder or U2 on occasion, when Gaye gets really earnest and political, the results can start to feel more naive and silly than significant or insightful. Case in point, Gayes repeated, almost hysterical cries to “Save the babies” on fourth track Save the Children, a short stretch that remains to this day one of the most unintentionally laughable moments ever put down on vinyl.

A bit overrated. Let’s Get It On is a better album, but since the lyrical content of What’s Going On is deeper, people have a tendency to overlook its flaws. I mean, it’s not really “enlightened” to say you like the album about sex more than the “serious” one. But, you know, Let’s Get It On is a more consistent album, with eighty quality songs. There are no duds. But What’s Going On has a few duds. And something I can never get past when I listen to What’s Going On … Mercy Mercy Me (The Ecology) is the same music as the title track! Almost exactly!

To me it was and is a masterpiece that transported me over and over. Still have the LP vinyl in my collection and feel reluctant to part with it in spite of there being no room for it in my new place. “Makes me wanna holler.”
Motown’s finest hour. One of the ten best studio albums of the rock era, regardless of genre. Up there with Revolver, Exile on Main St., Never Mind The Bollocks, Bitches Brew, and Pet Sounds.
I think personally that I wouldn't listen much to Marvin Gaye but I think the tone is kind of dance along and very smooth. Not bad sounding so far but not my style of music.
